title: Bio
text: Hello! My name is Christopher Lawrence. I’m a PhD candidate at the Atmospheric Sciences Research Center (ASRC) at the University of Albany. I assist the Lance Lab with the cloud water monitoring site at the summit of Whiteface Mountain in the Adirondack Mountains. I use observations and modeling techniques to investigate the role of cloud chemical processing on organic carbon in the aqueous and particle phases, and how they interact with other inorganic species. My research interests include biogeochemistry of organic carbon (particularly in the atmospheric aqueous phase), organic carbon and nitrogen interactions, wet deposition, the carbon cycle, and statistics.

title: Current Research
text:
I help assist the cloud water monitoring program at the summit of Whiteface Mountain that has been operating since 1994. The site was founded to monitor acid deposition and the progress of the Clean Air Act Amendments of the 1990s. Acid deposition is cause by the formation for strong inorganic acids such has sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and nitric acid (HNO3). In particular, sulfuric acid largely produced from sulfur dioxide (SO2) , a gas released from the combustion of coal. Regulations like the Clean Air Act Amendments and the decreasing coal consumption in the United States, acid deposition has decreased significantly and Adirondack ecosystems are starting to show signs of recovery. However, another class of compounds may be on the rise: organic carbon. Organic carbon is a complex class of compounds with at least tens of thousands of different molecules found in the natural environment. Gas phase organic compounds called Volatile Organic Compounds or VOCS, play a crucial role in the formation of ozone, a hazardous pollutant. Organic carbon can also contribute to the particulate matter, another hazardous that can also in interact with Earth’s climate by interacting with solar radiation, and change the formation of clouds and precipitation. Organic Carbon is representing a growing fraction of particulate matter in many regions of the world including WFM, and is potentially increasing in WFM cloud water. Investigating underlying causes of the increasing trend in organic carbon remains an active part of my work.



Changing chemical composition of major chemical species in Whiteface Mountain cloud water. Figure from Lawrence et al, 2023

title: So Why Did You Make This?
text:
Hello! Thanks for visiting Larry Loves Music. My name is Chris Lawrence but a lot of people in my life call me Larry. For a long time, I’ve been pretty obsessed with music. In highschool I had the opportunity to do a research project of my choosing. For whatever, I chose to research the impact the Beatles had on popular music. For this project, I got to spend my lunch periods reading about the Beatles and listening to all kind of music. This triggered an interest in music that I had never felt before and would change the way I listened to music in the future.

My First List
Fast forward several years. it was approaching finals week in my junior year at SUNY-ESF (go Mighty Oaks!), I unsurprisingly was finding myself in the library quite frequently either studying or working on final class projects. I was looking for something to help things bit more bearable. While procrastinating, I stumbled on to two different music related wesbites. The first was Album of the Year. Album of the year is social network/blog type website not dissimilar to sites like Rate Your Music. However, an important difference that also serves as a database for both reviews from music critics and users of the website. This serves as useful aggregator of what music people are interested in. Since occur in early December, it was also “list season”; where major publications release their lists for the top albums of the year. Album of the Year also compiles this information with point totals to provide a consensus album of the year. I found this whole process incredibly fascinating and a lot of fun, particularly when an album you like is seeing a lot of love.
The second outlet is from an NPR podcast that I had already been regularly listening to for about year, All Songs Considered. This is a wonderful music podcast hosted by Bob Boilen (the same person who created Tiny Desk Concerts) and Robin Hilton. They had just released a pod discussing listener picks for the best albums of the year. For whatever reason, I found (and still find this…) fascinating. This got me thinking about what my favorite albums of the past year were and inspired me to make my own list. I then wrote down some 30 albums, and listened to each one during finals week and picked my 10 favorites. This was the beginning of a yearly tradition at the end of the year where I listen to a barrage of music to make my list.


Going Forward
This website has 3 major purpose:

Compile all of my lists and playlists into one place for ease of access
Improve coding and writing skills with a website/pseudoblog project
Make it easier to share my favorite music with a potentially larger audience

This website is a major work in process. I’m still working out many bugs in the website, filling out its contents, and just making things look pretty. I will be constantly be editing things as there will no doubt be typos everywhere. I’m also not particularly adept of this style of writing so this a learning experience for me. I absolutely would love to hear any suggestions from people on what else I should do for this website. I’m thinking about a blog as well but not sure what exactly to blog about. Stay tuned!

title: Current Research
text:
Clouds cover vast areas of the Earth’s atmosphere and tightly coupled to precipitation, regulating our climate, and interacts and changes the atmosphere’s chemical composition. The role of cloud water chemistry was first discovered in 1970s as acid rain was negatively ecosystems in places like the Northeast United States and Europe, leaving lakes fishless and causing widespread decline of tree species like the red spruce. After research projects was discovered that unique chemistry chemistry occurring in cloud droplets converts gases like sulfur dioxide (SO2) released during the combustion of fossil like coal, to acidic compounds like sulfuric acid (H2SO4). These negative impacts on ecosystems helped shape the Clean Air Act Amendments in 1990s, aimed at reducing emissions of harmful pollutants like SO2 and to great success!
The cloud water monitoring program at Whiteface Mountain has been operating between June-September since 1994, founded to monitor the progress of the Clean Air Act Amendments.
